Section 3.2 Servicing of Receivables.
(a) General Servicing Obligations. The Servicer will manage, service, administer and collect on the Receivables with reasonable care using that degree of skill and attention that the Servicer exercises for all comparable device payment plan agreement receivables that it services for itself or others according to the Servicing Procedures. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the Servicer’s obligations will include:
(i) collecting and applying all payments made on, or credits applied to, the Receivables and any other amounts received related to the Depositor Transferred Property;
(ii) investigating delinquencies;
(iii) sending invoices and notices and responding to inquiries of Obligors;
(iv) processing requests for extensions, modifications and adjustments;
(v) administering payoffs, prepayments, defaults and delinquencies;
(vi) maintaining accurate and complete accounts and receivables systems for servicing the Receivables;
(vii) providing to the Custodian copies, or access to, any documents that modify or supplement information in the Receivable Files; and
(viii) preparing and providing Monthly Investor Reports and any other periodic reports required to be prepared by the Servicer under this Agreement or any other Transaction Document.
perturbation.changed_text:
Section 3.2 Servicing of Receivables.
(a) General Servicing Obligations. The Servicer will manage, service, administer and collect on the Receivables with reasonable care using that degree of skill and attention that the Servicer exercises for some comparable device payment plan agreement receivables that it services for itself or others according to the Servicing Procedures. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the Servicer’s obligations will include:
(i) collecting and applying all payments made on, or credits applied to, the Receivables and any other amounts received related to the Depositor Transferred Property;
(ii) investigating delinquencies, though not necessarily all of them;
(iii) sending invoices and notices when deemed appropriate and responding to some inquiries of Obligors;
(iv) processing requests for extensions, modifications and adjustments, selectively;
(v) administering payoffs, prepayments, defaults and delinquencies on a best effort basis;
(vi) maintaining accounts and receivables systems for servicing the Receivables, but accuracy is not guaranteed;
(vii) providing to the Custodian copies, or access to, some documents that modify or supplement information in the Receivable Files; and
(viii) preparing and providing Monthly Investor Reports and any other periodic reports required to be prepared by the Servicer under this Agreement or any other Transaction Document. The servicer does not guarantee the accuracy of these reports.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces ambiguity by weakening the language of the Servicer's obligations. Phrases like 'some comparable device payment plan agreement receivables,' 'though not necessarily all of them,' 'when deemed appropriate,' 'selectively,' 'on a best effort basis,' 'accuracy is not guaranteed,' and 'some documents' all create loopholes and uncertainty regarding the Servicer's responsibilities. This contradicts the original intent of the section, which outlined clear and comprehensive servicing obligations. This change could allow the servicer to service in an arbitrary and self-serving way, as long as they could find some aspect of their behaviour that was reasonable.

Section 3.3 Servicer’s Acquisition of Receivables.
(a) Acquisition for Servicer Modifications. If extensions, modifications, amendments, cancellations or waivers of Receivables or any terms thereof are made that would require such Receivables to be acquired under Section 3.2(b), the Servicer will acquire all such Receivables as set forth in Section 3.3(d).
(b) Acquisition for Breach of Servicer’s Obligations. If a Responsible Person of the Servicer receives written notice from the Depositor, the Issuer, the Owner Trustee or the

perturbation.changed_text:
Section 3.3 Servicer’s Acquisition of Receivables.
(a) Acquisition for Servicer Modifications. If extensions, modifications, amendments, cancellations or waivers of Receivables or any terms thereof are made that would require such Receivables to be acquired under Section 3.2(b), the Servicer may, at its discretion, acquire such Receivables as set forth in Section 3.3(d).
(b) Acquisition for Breach of Servicer’s Obligations. If a Responsible Person of the Servicer receives written notice from the Depositor, the Issuer, the Owner Trustee or the
9
Source: VERIZON ABS LLC, 8-K, 1/23/2020
Indenture Trustee of a breach of the Servicer’s obligations in Section 3.2(c) or (d), and the Servicer deems the breach significant, the Servicer may elect to acquire Receivables with respect to which such breach was not so cured as set forth in Section 3.3(d).
(c) Acquisition for System Limitation or Inability to Service. If the Servicer determines that as a result of a receivables
systems error or receivables systems limitation or for what the Servicer considers to be any other legitimate reason the Servicer is somewhat challenged to service a Receivable according to the Servicing
Procedures and the terms of this Agreement, the Servicer may acquire the relevant Receivable as set forth in Section 3.3(d).
perturbation.explanation: Here, the mandatory 'will acquire' is replaced by the permissive 'may acquire', giving the servicer discretion where previously there was an obligation. The introduction of subjective qualifications like 'deems the breach significant', 'somewhat challenged,' and 'legitimate reason' create significant loopholes that make it difficult to enforce the acquisition requirement. This directly contradicts the purpose of the original section, which was designed to ensure that the Servicer bears the cost of its errors and deviations from agreed servicing procedures. This creates uncertainty and potential disputes over whether the Servicer is required to acquire specific Receivables.

perturbation.original_text:
Section 3.10 Custodian.
(a) Appointment of Custodian. To reduce administrative costs and facilitate the servicing of the Receivables by the Servicer, the Issuer
appoints Cellco, in its capacity as the Servicer, to act as the Custodian of the Receivables for the Issuer and the Indenture Trustee (for the benefit of
the Secured Parties), as their interests may appear. Cellco accepts the appointment and agrees to perform the custodial obligations in this Section
3.10.
(b) Custody of Receivable Files. The Custodian will hold and maintain in custody the following documents for each Receivable (the
“Receivable File”) for the benefit of the Issuer and the Indenture Trustee, using reasonable care and according to the Servicing Procedures:
(i) the original Receivable (or an imaged copy of such Receivable) or an authoritative copy of the Receivable, if in electronic form;
and
(ii) all other documents, notices and correspondence relating to the Receivable or the Obligor that the Servicer generates in the
course of servicing the Receivable.
Except as stated above, any document in a Receivable File may be a photocopy or in electronic format or may be converted to electronic
format at any time. The Custodian will hold and maintain the Receivable Files, including any receivables systems on which the Receivable Files are
electronically stored, in a manner that will permit the Servicer and the Issuer to comply with this Agreement and the Indenture Trustee to comply
with the Indenture.
perturbation.changed_text:
Section 3.10 Custodian.
(a) Appointment of Custodian. To reduce administrative costs and facilitate the servicing of the Receivables by the Servicer, the Issuer may appoint Cellco, in its capacity as the Servicer, to act as the Custodian of the Receivables for the Issuer and the Indenture Trustee (for the benefit of the Secured Parties), as their interests may appear. Cellco may accept the appointment and may agree to perform some custodial obligations in this Section 3.10.
(b) Custody of Receivable Files. The Custodian will endeavor to hold and maintain in custody some documents for each Receivable (the
“Receivable File”) for the benefit of the Issuer and the Indenture Trustee, using what it believes to be reasonable care, but need not necessarily perform all servicing procedures. The documents could include:
(i) the original Receivable (or if that is somehow not possible, another copy) or a copy of the Receivable, if it is readily available;
and
(ii) documents, notices and correspondence relating to the Receivable or the Obligor that the Servicer generates if it is not too much trouble to find them.
Any document in a Receivable File may be a photocopy or in electronic format or may be converted to electronic
format at some point. The Custodian will attempt to hold and maintain the Receivable Files, including any receivables systems on which the Receivable Files are
electronically stored, in a manner that will allow the Servicer and the Issuer to generally comply with this Agreement and the Indenture Trustee to somewhat comply with the Indenture.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text uses significantly weaker and more ambiguous language than the original. Words like 'may appoint,' 'may agree to perform some custodial obligations,' 'endeavor,' 'what it believes to be reasonable care,' 'need not necessarily perform all servicing procedures,' 'if that is somehow not possible,' 'another copy,' 'if it is readily available,' 'if it is not too much trouble to find them,' 'at some point,' and 'generally comply' create uncertainty regarding the Custodian's duties and responsibilities. This could potentially lead to disputes over the Custodian's performance and whether it has adequately fulfilled its obligations. It's unclear what the 'some documents' will be, if the obligations won't be followed, and the ambiguity introduced has the potential to render this section unenforceable.
